speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English and I'm Neil. Joining me for our discussion is Georgina.

speaker: Georgina
text: Hello!

speaker: Neil
text: Now, Georgina, you’re a chatty, sociable kind of person, aren’t you?

speaker: Georgina
text: Well, yes, I think so.

speaker: Neil
text: But would you go up to a stranger and strike up a conversation?

speaker: Georgina
text: That might be going too far – if you don’t know them, what are you going to start talking about?

speaker: Neil
text: A good question. But maybe you should – because in this programme we’re looking at how talking to strangers might actually be good for you! But first, let me talk to you about today’s question. I’d like you to answer this. To make conversation we need words – so according to the Oxford English dictionary, approximately how many words are in use in the English language? Is it…

speaker: Georgina
text: We use a lot of words in English, but not 371,000 – so I’ll go for a) 171,146.

speaker: Neil
text: OK. Well, as always I will reveal the answer later in the programme.

speaker: Neil
text: Now, let’s continue our conversation about having conversations with strangers! Many of us spend part of every day surrounded by strangers, whether on our commute to work, sitting in a park or cafe, or visiting the supermarket.

speaker: Georgina
text: But we rarely reach out and talk to them because we fear it would make us both feel uncomfortable – or awkward. And Gillian Sandstrom, social psychologist from Essex University in the UK, can explain why. Here she is speaking on BBC Radio 4’s All In The Mind programme….

speaker: underestimateanticipating
text: We kind of underestimate, we have this negative voice in our head that's telling us "I shouldn't have said that, why did I do that? I said that story better last time". But the other person doesn't know any of that and they’re probably… they might be anticipating that they won't have a positive conversation and then they do. And they think, wow, that person was amazing. So we walk round with this fear that the other person isn’t going to be interested in talking to us.

speaker: underestimate
text: Fascinating stuff. So we have a negative voice in our head telling us about all the bad things that might happen. We basically underestimate ourselves.

speaker: Neil
text: To underestimate means to think that something is smaller or less important than it really is. We worry that what we say won’t be interesting or important enough.

speaker: anticipating
text: Ah, but the other person doesn’t know that. They’re also anticipating – or guessing - the outcome. They're thinking that if they have a conversation, it won’t go well. But of course, when strangers do talk to each other it normally goes well.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, it’s just fear that is stopping us. But if we get over that fear, and get chatting, people might actually like us – and we might make new friends.

speaker: pluck up the courage
text: Another reason why you should pluck up the courage to talk to strangers is that it’s good for our health!

speaker: Pluck up the courageconnecting
text: ‘Pluck up the courage’ – that’s a good phrase, Georgina, meaning force yourself to do something that you’re scared about and… research by the University of Chicago found we may often underestimate the positive impact of connecting with others for both our own and others' wellbeing.

speaker: connecting
text: And connecting here means starting or having a good relationship with someone. So the research found that, for example, having a conversation with a stranger on your way to work may leave you both feeling happier than you would think.

speaker: Neil
text: Gillian Sandstrom also spoke about her research and the power of talking to strangers on the You and Yours programme. Listen out for the word ‘connected’…

speaker: moodconnected
text: What we've shown in the research is that it's really good for your mood. So people are in a better mood after they reach out and have a conversation, however minimal, and the other thing that the research has shown is that just makes people feel more connected to each other.

speaker: moodmood
text: There you go! Talking to strangers is good for our mood – and mood means the way we feel. It’s good for our mental health – and we might discover people actually like us!

speaker: introvert
text: And even if we’re an introvert – a person who prefers to be alone rather than with other people - experiments have shown that talking to others can make us happier.

speaker: Georgina
text: The problem remains, Neil, that when speaking to someone new, what do you talk about?

speaker: Neil
text: How about some interesting facts – like approximately how many words are in use in the English language? Which is what I asked you earlier. Is it?

speaker: Neil
text: What did you say, Georgina?

speaker: Georgina
text: I said 171,146. Was I right?

speaker: Neil
text: Spot on, Georgina. Well done! Yes, there are an estimated 171,146 words currently in use in the English language, according to the Oxford English Dictionary –plus many more obsolete words.

speaker: Georgina
text: I shall pick a few of them and make conversation with someone on the Tube later, but not before we recap some of the vocabulary we’ve explained.

speaker: underestimate
text: Yes – so we highlighted six words, starting with underestimate which is to think that something is smaller or less important than it really is.

speaker: Georgina
text: Anticipating means guessing or expecting a certain outcome. I anticipate this programme to be 6 minutes long!

speaker: to pluck up the courage
text: That’s a given! Next, we mentioned the phrase to pluck up the courage,meaning to force yourself to do something that you’re scared or nervous about.

speaker: connect
text: When you connect with someone, it means you start or have a good relationship with someone. I think we’ve connected on this programme, Neil!

speaker: mood
text: Absolutely, Georgina. And that’s put me in a good mood – mood means the way we feel.

speaker: introvert
text: And finally, an introvert is a person who prefers to spend time on their own.

speaker: Neil
text: Thanks, Georgina.  Well, that’s our conversation over, but you can hear more from us on our website and on our app. Goodbye!

speaker: Georgina
text: Bye!
